I wasn't planning to automate the generation.  What I am finding is that 
there are a many compile cases to be tested but not so many as that they 
would need to be generated automatically.  So, unless Java could execute 
the good code and only throw an exception when it hits bad code, it 
seems that the code snippets need to be encapsulated somehow and 
compiled and executed at runtime.

I haven't looked at java 1.6 or at sun's Main.  I'll add these to my 
list, but it seems that whatever the solution, the context of the test 
case would have to be included, with each test case including a copy of 
all the supporting code.  This would require some manner of automation 
to take a line of code, embed it in an automatically generated program 
with all of its contextual code, and then try and compile each test case.

Hmmmmm.  Another approach would be to isolate the test case method 
containing the questionable code snippets, enclosing each code snippet 
to be tested for compile errors in some JUnit call, perhaps with the 
line to be tested passed as a String.  Then one at a time, JUnit would 
exclude all but one of these code snippets while trying to compile the 
whole test method.  In this manner, the compile assertion test would 
(hopefully) appear and work much like ordinary dynamic testing using JUnit.

Being a consumer of JUnit, not a developer, please forgive me if my 
"solution" fails to make any sense.

--jon

> Message: 5 Date: Wed May 31, 2006 12:51 pm (PDT) From: "Mark Salter" marksalter@... Subject: Re: testing for compile Jon Barrilleaux wrote:
> 
>>> How do you test to make sure that what you think should happen actually 
>>> happens at compile time?  Don't forget that JUnit is about regression 
>>> testing.  If you make some change in the type hierarchies or 
>>> implementations, how do you make sure you haven't broken the 
>>> compile-time enforcement of what should and should not be allowed...
> 
> 
> Without actually compiling all of the code, I'm not sure you can precisely.
> Perhaps the trick is to compile just the code you can predict the 
> expected outcome for and check it conforms.
> 
> Could
>      sun.tools.javac.Main (JDK 1.5)
> or
>      javax.tools.JavaCompilerTool (JDK 1.6+)
> 
> help in your aim?  These appear to be two ways of invoking javac directly.
> 
> If you could invoke the compiler in this way - perhaps once for each 
> test source element, you could use JUnit to assertTrue/False on the return.
> 
> The run method of JavaCompilerTool returns a boolean :-
> 
> "
> true if and only all the files compiled without errors; false otherwise
> "
> 
> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> DelegatorA.getNodeOut().connectTo(DelegatorB.getNodeIn()); // no error
> 
> [snip]
> 
>>> SubDelegA.getNodeIn().connectTo(SubDelegB.getNodeOut()); // no error
>>> 
>>> etc, etc, etc....
> 
> 
> Will you be attempting to generate the possible combinations, if so, can 
> you predict within the generation what should and shouldn't compile?
> 
> 
>>> 
>>> So, is there any way for JUnit to include an assertion for a compile 
>>> time error?  Earlier attempts on my part, and suggestions by others, 
>>> have been unsuccessful.  Is this something that is currently impossible 
>>> in Java?
> 
> 
> I admit, I have not looked through your other threads, so if this 
> suggestion has been made and rejected already, please forgive my laziness!
> 
> -- Mark
